case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Respondent

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 192 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 192 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 27, 1958 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 395 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 27, 1958, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Criminal Revision Case No. 395 of 1958.

facts.text: Respondent convicted by Judicial Magistrate of Adoni under section 14 of Foreigners Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was companyvicted by the Judicial Magistrate of Adoni in the State of Andhra Pradesh, under s. 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946.

facts.text: Appeal to Sessions Judge of Kurnool dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: His appeal to the Sessions Judge of Kurnool was dismissed.

facts.text: Revision petition to High Court of Andhra Pradesh allowed.

anchor.surface_text: He then moved the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in revision and the revision petition was allowed.

facts.text: Present appeal by State of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the present appeal by the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Respondent came to Adoni on January 20, 1955 on passport granted by Government of Pakistan dated January 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On January 20, 1955, the respondent had companye to Adoni on a passport granted by the Government of Pakistan which bore the date January 10, 1955.

facts.text: Passport had visa permitting stay in India up to April 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The passport had endorsed on it a visa granted by the Indian authorities which permitted the respondent to stay in India up to April 14, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent continued to stay in India after April 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytinued to stay on in India after that date.

facts.text: Respondent made representation to Government of India for visa extension till September 2, 1957 on health grounds.

anchor.surface_text: On some date, number precisely ascertainable from the record, he appears to have made a representation to the Government of India for extension of his visa till September 2, 1957, on grounds of health.

facts.text: Records do not show any order made on the representation.

anchor.surface_text: The records do number however show what order, if any, was made on this representation.

facts.text: On September 3, 1957, order dated August 9, 1957 by Government of Andhra Pradesh to leave India served on respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On September 3, 1957, an order dated August 9, 1957, made by the Government of Andhra, Pradesh requiring him to leave India, was served on the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent did not leave India as directed and was prosecuted.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent did number leave India as directed by this order, he was prosecuted with the result earlier stated.

facts.text: Passport showed respondent born at Adoni in 1924.

anchor.surface_text: The passport showed that the respondent was born at Adoni in 1924.

facts.text: Respondent produced extract from municipal birth register showing birth at Adoni.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appears to have produced an extract from the municipal birth register, which is number on the record, but presumably showed that he was so born.

facts.text: Evidence shows respondent left India at end of 1954 or early 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The only evidence on the record of the date when he left India, shows that must have been at the end of 1954 or early in 1955.

facts.text: Respondent paying rent for shop at Adoni for about ten years prior to 1958.

anchor.surface_text: There is evidence to show that he had been paying rent for his -,hop at Adoni for about ten years prior to 1958.

facts.text: Respondent's parents, brothers, wife and children were and had always been in India.

anchor.surface_text: and his parent s. brothers, wife, and children were. and bad always been in India.

facts.text: Respondent charged with breach of order under section 3(2)(c) of Foreigners Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was charged with the breach of the order to leave India which had been made under s. 3  2  c  of the Foreigners Act.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate found respondent disowned Indian nationality by obtaining Pakistan passport.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Magistrate found that by obtaining the passport from the Pakistan authorities, he has disowned Indian nationality and has ceased to be an Indian National.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate held section 8 of Foreigners Act applies and government decision final.

anchor.surface_text: He also held that s. 9 of the Foreigners Act did number apply to the case but s. 8 of that Act did and that under that section a decision made by the Government that a person is a foreigner is final.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held respondent's conduct in applying for extension shows not Indian citizen.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to the decision of the learned Sessions Judge, he seems to have based himself on the reasoning that the companyduct of the appellant that is, the respondent before us, in applying for extension of time shows that he is number a citizen of India.

facts.text: Evidence shows respondent went to Pakistan end 1954 or beginning 1955 for short time.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence shows that the respondent did go to Pakistan, but the only evidence with regard to that is that he went there about the end of 1954 or the beginning of 1955. This evidence also indicates that he stayed there for a short time.

facts.text: Respondent discharged onus under section 9 Foreigners Act by proving born and domiciled in India prior to January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has clearly discharged the onus that lay on him under s. 9 of the Foreigners Act to prove that he was number a foreigner, by proving that he was born and domiciled in India prior to January 26, 1950.

facts.text: No decision by Central Government under section 9 Citizenship Act that respondent acquired foreign nationality.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been shown that the Central Government had made any decision with regard to him under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act that he has acquired a foreign nationality.

issues.text: The question is, was [the respondent] a foreigner?

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was charged with the breach of the order to leave India which had been made under s. 3  2  c  of the Foreigners Act. Now the order could not be made on him, neither could he be convicted for breach of it, if lie was number a foreigner. That was the defence of the respondent, namely that he was number a foreigner. The question is, was a foreigner?

issues.text: Whether s. 8 of the Foreigners Act applies to the case to determine the respondent's nationality?

anchor.surface_text: s. 9 of the Foreigners Act did number apply to the case but s. 8 of that Act did and that under that section a decision made by the Government that a person is a foreigner is final and such a decision had been made in this case regarding the respondent as the Government had decided number to grant him an extension of his visa. On these grounds he found that the respondent was a foreigner. It seems to us that both these grounds are untenable. Section 8 applies to a case where a foreigner is recognised as a national by the law of more than one foreign companyntry or where for any reason, it is uncertain what nationality if any is to be ascribed to a foreigner.

issues.text: Whether the courts have jurisdiction to decide if an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another country?

anchor.surface_text: s. 9 2  of the Citizenship Act, 1955, provides that if any question arises as to whether an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another companyntry, it shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as may be prescribed. Under r. 30 of the rules framed under that Act,, the authority to decide that question is the Central Government. So the question whether the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired Pakistani citizenship cannot be decided by companyrts.

issues.text: Whether the Central Government had decided that the respondent had acquired Pakistani citizenship?

anchor.surface_text: Nor was there anything before the learned Magistrate to show that the Central Government had decided that the respondent had renounced Indian citizenship and acquired that of Pakistan. The learned Magistrate thought -that the fact that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa proved that it had decided that he had acquired Pakistani nationality. This view again was number warranted. There is numberhing to show that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa. Even if it had, that would number amount to a decision by it, that the respon- dent, an Indian citizen, had acquired subsequently Pakistani nationality

issues.text: Whether the respondent discharged the onus under s. 9 of the Foreigners Act to prove he was not a foreigner?

anchor.surface_text: under s. 9 of the Foreigners Act to prove that he was number a foreigner, by proving that he was born and domiciled in India prior to January 26, 1950, when the Constitution came into force and thereby had become an Indian citizen under Art. 5 a  of the Constitution. He has further proved that he had never migrated to Pakistan. It has number been shown that the Central Government had made any decision with regard to him under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act that he has acquired a foreign nationality.

issues.text: Whether Art. 7 of the Constitution contemplates migration from India to Pakistan after January 26, 1950?

arguments.claim: Respondent was not a foreigner

anchor.surface_text: Now the order could not be made on him, neither could he be convicted for breach of it, if he was not a foreigner. That was the defence of the respondent, namely that he was not a foreigner. The question is, was he a foreigner?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the Foreigners Act. Conviction for breach of such an order by the respondent would be wholly illegal. Though we are upholding the decision of the High

arguments.court_reasoning: Respondent discharged onus under s.9 Foreigners Act by proving birth and domicile in India prior to 26.1.1950; no migration; no Central Govt decision under Citizenship Act s.9

arguments.claim: By obtaining Pakistan passport, respondent disowned Indian nationality and ceased to be Indian national

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Magistrate found that by obtaining the passport from the Pakistan authorities, he has disowned Indian nationality and has ceased to be an Indian National.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to decide of which companyntry the foreigner is to be treated as the national and such decision shall be final. The section, therefore, applies to a

arguments.court_reasoning: Courts have no jurisdiction to decide if Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship; requires Central Govt decision under Citizenship Act s.9(2) and r.30

arguments.claim: s.9 Foreigners Act does not apply but s.8 does; govt decision that person is foreigner is final; visa extension refusal is such decision

anchor.surface_text: He also held that s. 9 of the Foreigners Act did not apply to the case but s. 8 of that Act did and that under that section a decision made by the Government that a person is a foreigner is final and such a decision had been made in this case regarding the respondent as the Government had decided not to grant him an extension of his visa.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ble. Section 8 applies to a case where a foreigner is recognised as a national by the law of more than one foreign companyntry or where for any reason

arguments.court_reasoning: s.8 applies only to known foreigner to decide which foreign country nationality; not to decide if person is foreigner

arguments.claim: Central Govt refusal to extend visa proves it decided respondent acquired Pakistani nationality

anchor.surface_text: Nor was there anything before the learned Magistrate to show that the Central Government had decided that the respondent had renounced Indian citizenship and acquired that of Pakistan. The learned Magistrate thought that the fact that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa proved that it had decided that he had acquired Pakistani nationality.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: enounced Indian citizenship and acquired that of Pakistan. The learned Magistrate thought -that the fact that the Central Government had refused to ex

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of refusal by Central Govt; even if refused, not a decision under s.9(2) Citizenship Act requiring enquiry under r.30

arguments.claim: Respondent's conduct in applying for visa extension shows he is not Indian citizen and acquired Pakistan citizenship

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the decision of the learned Sessions Judge, he seems to have based himself on the reasoning that the conduct of the appellant that is, the respondent before us, in applying for extension of time shows that he is not a citizen of India and that he has acquired citizenship of Pakistan.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er have been warranted. For all these reasons we think that the companyviction of the respondent by the learned Magistrate was number well founded. Co

arguments.court_reasoning: Courts cannot decide if Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship; only Central Govt under Citizenship Act s.9(2) and r.30

arguments.claim: If respondent were Indian citizen, he would raise plea and let Central Govt decide instead of applying for extension

anchor.surface_text: If he were a citizen of India, he could have raised this plea and this question could have been decided by the Central Government as envisaged by Rule 30, sub-Rule (1) of the Rules made under the Citizenship Act and there was no necessity to apply for extension.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s Judge, he seems to have based himself on the reasoning that the companyduct of the appellant that is, the respondent before us, in applying for exte

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumes court can decide acquisition of foreign citizenship, which it cannot

arguments.claim: s.8 Foreigners Act applies only to deciding which foreign country a known foreigner belongs to

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 applies to a case where a foreigner is recognised as a national by the law of more than one foreign country or where for any reason, it is uncertain what nationality if any is to be ascribed to a foreigner. The section provides that in such cases the prescribed authority has power to decide of which country the foreigner is to be treated as the national and such decision shall be final.

arguments.claim: Magistrate erred in relying on s.8 Foreigners Act

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate therefore clearly went wrong in relying on s. 8.

arguments.claim: Courts have no jurisdiction to decide if Indian citizen acquired citizenship of another country

anchor.surface_text: Now, s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, 1955, provides that if any question arises as to whether an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another country, it shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as may be prescribed. Under r. 30 of the rules framed under that Act, the authority to decide that question is the Central Government.

arguments.claim: No evidence Central Govt decided respondent acquired Pakistani citizenship

anchor.surface_text: Nor was there anything before the learned Magistrate to show that the Central Government had decided that the respondent had renounced Indian citizenship and acquired that of Pakistan.

arguments.claim: Visa refusal does not amount to Central Govt decision under Citizenship Act s.9(2)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate thought that the fact that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa proved that it had decided that he had acquired Pakistani nationality. This view again was not warranted. There is nothing to show that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa.

arguments.claim: Central Govt decision on acquisition of foreign nationality requires enquiry under r.30 Citizenship Rules

anchor.surface_text: Even if it had, that would not amount to a decision by it, that the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired subsequently Pakistani nationality for there may be such refusal when an applicant for the extension had all along been a Pakistani national. Furthermore, in order that there may be a decision by the Central Government that an Indian citizen has acquired foreign nationality, an enquiry as laid down in r. 30 of the rules framed under the Citizenship Act has to be made and no such enquiry had at all been made.

arguments.claim: Courts can decide if person is Indian citizen or foreigner ab initio, distinct from acquisition of foreign citizenship

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a person is an Indian citizen or a foreigner, as distinct from the question whether a person having once been an Indian citizen has renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign nationality, is not one which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Central Government to decide. The courts can decide it and, therefore, the learned Magistrate could have done so.

arguments.claim: Sessions Judge erred by deciding on acquisition of citizenship, which courts cannot

anchor.surface_text: Quite plainly, the learned Sessions Judge was proceeding on the basis that the respondent had renounced his Indian citizenship and acquired Pakistani citizenship. As we have said earlier, that is not a question which is open to a court to decide and there is no evidence to show that it has been decided by the Central Government who alone has the power to decide it.

arguments.claim: Evidence insufficient to hold respondent was foreigner from beginning

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge did not direct himself to the question which he could decide, namely whether the respondent had from the beginning been a Pakistani citizen. His decision, therefore, cannot also be sustained. We have examined the evidence on the record ourselves and are unable to say that a conviction can be based on it.

arguments.claim: Respondent never migrated to Pakistan; short visit not migration

anchor.surface_text: There can be no conviction unless it can be held on the evidence that the respondent is a foreigner, that is to say, a person who is not an Indian citizen see s. 2(a) of the Foreigners Act as amended by Act 11 of 1957. The evidence shows that the respondent did go to Pakistan, but the only evidence with regard to that is that he went there about the end of 1954 or the beginning of 1955. This evidence also indicates that he stayed there for a short time. He was all along paying the rent for his shop in Adoni. His family had always been there. Therefore it can be said that he had never migrated to Pakistan. Clearly, a short visit to Pakistan would not amount to migrating to that country.

arguments.claim: Pakistan passport evidence only relevant to acquisition of foreign citizenship, not usable by court

anchor.surface_text: The passport obtained by him from Pakistan would no doubt be evidence that he was a Pakistani national. As on the facts of this case he must be held to have been an Indian citizen on the promulgation of the Constitution, the passport can show no more than that he renounced Indian citizenship and acquired Pakistani nationality. Such evidence would be of no use in the present case for, in view of s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, a Court cannot decide whether an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another country.

arguments.claim: Respondent discharged onus under s.9 Foreigners Act; born and domiciled in India pre 26.1.1950; citizen under Art.5; no migration; no Central Govt decision under Citizenship s.9

anchor.surface_text: The position then is this. The respondent has clearly discharged the onus that lay on him under s. 9 of the Foreigners Act to prove that he was not a foreigner, by proving that he was born and domiciled in India prior to January 26, 1950, when the Constitution came into force and thereby had become an Indian citizen under Art. 5(a) of the Constitution. He has further proved that he had never migrated to Pakistan. It has not been shown that the Central Government had made any decision with regard to him under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act that he has acquired a foreign nationality.

arguments.claim: Art.7 Constitution does not contemplate migration to Pakistan after 26.1.1950 (disagreement with High Court)
arguments.court_reasoning: Reference in Art.7 to Arts.5 and 6 suggests pre-commencement migration; not endorsed

arguments.claim: Art.7 refers to migration before 26.1.1950

holdings.text: Section 8 of the Foreigners Act applies only to cases where a known foreigner has multiple or uncertain foreign nationalities, not to determine if a person is a foreigner or Indian citizen; Magistrate erred in relying on it.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 applies to a case where a foreigner is recognised as a national by the law of more than one foreign country or where for any reason, it is uncertain what nationality if any is to be ascribed to a foreigner. The section provides that in such cases the prescribed authority has power to decide of which country the foreigner is to be treated as the national and such decision shall be final. The learned Magistrate therefore clearly went wrong in relying on s. 8.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of s.8: presupposes person is already a foreigner; decides which foreign country nationality.

holdings.text: Courts have no jurisdiction to decide whether an Indian citizen has acquired citizenship of another country; such question to be decided only by Central Government under s.9(2) Citizenship Act and r.30 Citizenship Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Now, s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, 1955, provides that if any question arises as to whether an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another country, it shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as may be prescribed. Under r. 30 of the rules framed under that Act, the authority to decide that question is the Central Government. So the question whether the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired Pakistani citizenship cannot be decided by courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.9(2) Citizenship Act and r.30; exclusive jurisdiction of Central Govt after prescribed enquiry.

holdings.text: There was no decision by Central Government that respondent had acquired Pakistani citizenship; visa refusal (if any) does not constitute such decision without enquiry under r.30.

anchor.surface_text: Nor was there anything before the learned Magistrate to show that the Central Government had decided that the respondent had renounced Indian citizenship and acquired that of Pakistan. The learned Magistrate thought that the fact that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa proved that it had decided that he had acquired Pakistani nationality. This view again was not warranted. There is nothing to show that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa. Even if it had, that would not amount to a decision by it, that the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired subsequently Pakistani nationality for there may be such refusal when an applicant for the extension had all along been a Pakistani national. Furthermore, in order that there may be a decision by the Central Government that an Indian citizen has acquired foreign nationality, an enquiry as laid down in r. 30 of the rules framed under the Citizenship Act has to be made and no such enquiry had at all been made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of decision or enquiry; visa refusal insufficient as it lacks procedural requirements of r.30.

holdings.text: Courts have jurisdiction to determine whether a person is an Indian citizen or a foreigner ab initio, distinct from whether a citizen later acquired foreign nationality.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a person is an Indian citizen or a foreigner, as distinct from the question whether a person having once been an Indian citizen has renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign nationality, is not one which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Central Government to decide. The courts can decide it and, therefore, the learned Magistrate could have done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between initial citizenship status (justiciable by courts) and subsequent acquisition (exclusive to Central Govt).

holdings.text: Sessions Judge erred in basing decision on respondent's acquisition of Pakistani citizenship, as courts lack jurisdiction and no Central Govt decision exists; evidence insufficient to find respondent was foreigner from beginning.

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the decision of the learned Sessions Judge, he seems to have based himself on the reasoning that the conduct of the appellant that is, the respondent before us, in applying for extension of time shows that he is not a citizen of India and that he has acquired citizenship of Pakistan... Quite plainly, the learned Sessions Judge was proceeding on the basis that the respondent had renounced his Indian citizenship and acquired Pakistani citizenship. As we have said earlier, that is not a question which is open to a court to decide... The learned Sessions Judge did not direct himself to the question which he could decide, namely whether the respondent had from the beginning been a Pakistani citizen. His decision, therefore, cannot also be sustained. We have examined the evidence on the record ourselves and are unable to say that a conviction can be based on it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wrong question addressed; independent evidence review shows insufficiency.

holdings.text: Short visit to Pakistan does not amount to migration; respondent never migrated to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence shows that the respondent did go to Pakistan, but the only evidence with regard to that is that he went there about the end of 1954 or the beginning of 1955. This evidence also indicates that he stayed there for a short time. He was all along paying the rent for his shop in Adoni. His family had always been there. Therefore it can be said that he had never migrated to Pakistan. Clearly, a short visit to Pakistan would not amount to migrating to that country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of brief stay, continuous ties to India preclude migration.

holdings.text: Pakistan passport evidence relevant only to possible subsequent acquisition of foreign citizenship, which court cannot decide; inadmissible for that purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The passport obtained by him from Pakistan would no doubt be evidence that he was a Pakistani national. As on the facts of this case he must be held to have been an Indian citizen on the promulgation of the Constitution, the passport can show no more than that he renounced Indian citizenship and acquired Pakistani nationality. Such evidence would be of no use in the present case for, in view of s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, a Court cannot decide whether an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presupposes initial citizenship; s.9(2) bars court consideration of acquisition.

holdings.text: Respondent discharged onus under s.9 Foreigners Act by proving birth and domicile in India prior to 26.1.1950 (citizen under Art.5(a)), no migration, no Central Govt decision under Citizenship Act s.9; thus not a foreigner.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has clearly discharged the onus that lay on him under s. 9 of the Foreigners Act to prove that he was not a foreigner, by proving that he was born and domiciled in India prior to January 26, 1950, when the Constitution came into force and thereby had become an Indian citizen under Art. 5 a of the Constitution. He has further proved that he had never migrated to Pakistan. It has not been shown that the Central Government had made any decision with regard to him under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act that he has acquired a foreign nationality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preponderance of evidence on birth/domicile; absence of disqualifying factors.

holdings.text: No valid order under s.3(2)(c) Foreigners Act against Indian citizen; conviction under s.14 for breach thereof illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it cannot be held by any court that the respondent who was an Indian citizen has ceased to be such and become a foreigner. That being so, it must be held for the purpose of this case that the respondent was not a foreigner and no order could be made against him under s. 3(2)(c) of the Foreigners Act. Conviction for breach of such an order by the respondent would be wholly illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(2)(c) applies only to foreigners; respondent citizen.

holdings.text: Court does not endorse High Court's view that Art.7 contemplates migration from India to Pakistan after 26.1.1950; likely refers to pre-commencement migration (not finally decided).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/harmonious construction suggests pre-1950; unnecessary to case facts.

anchor.surface_text: Though we are upholding the decision of the High Court, we wish to observe that we do number do so for the reasons mentioned by it. It is unnecessary to discuss those reasons but we would like to point, out one thing, namely. that the High

outcome.relief_summary: Upholding High Court order allowing revision petition, thereby quashing respondent's conviction as he is not a foreigner

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 applies to a case where a foreigner is recognised as a national by the law of more than one foreign country or where for any reason, it is uncertain what nationality if any is to be ascribed to a foreigner. The section provides that in such cases the prescribed authority has power to decide of which country the foreigner is to be treated as the national and such decision shall be final. The learned Magistrate therefore clearly went wrong in relying on s. 8.

Though we are upholding the decision of the High Court, we wish to observe that we do number do so for the reasons mentioned by it. It is unnecessary to discuss those reasons but we would like to point, out one thing, namely. that the High

edges.explanation: Holding directly addresses the issue of whether courts have jurisdiction to decide acquisition of foreign citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: Now, s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act, 1955, provides that if any question arises as to whether an Indian citizen has acquired the citizenship of another country, it shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as may be prescribed. Under r. 30 of the rules framed under that Act, the authority to decide that question is the Central Government. So the question whether the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired Pakistani citizenship cannot be decided by courts.

Though we are upholding the decision of the High Court, we wish to observe that we do number do so for the reasons mentioned by it. It is unnecessary to discuss those reasons but we would like to point, out one thing, namely. that the High
n whether the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired Pakistani citizenship cannot be decided by companyrts. The learned Magistrate had numberjuri

edges.explanation: holding explicitly states no decision by Central Government on Pakistani citizenship, directly addressing the issue

anchor.surface_text: Nor was there anything before the learned Magistrate to show that the Central Government had decided that the respondent had renounced Indian citizenship and acquired that of Pakistan. The learned Magistrate thought that the fact that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa proved that it had decided that he had acquired Pakistani nationality. This view again was not warranted. There is nothing to show that the Central Government had refused to extend the respondents visa. Even if it had, that would not amount to a decision by it, that the respondent, an Indian citizen, had acquired subsequently Pakistani nationality for there may be such refusal when an applicant for the extension had all along been a Pakistani national. Furthermore, in order that there may be a decision by the Central Government that an Indian citizen has acquired foreign nationality, an enquiry as laid down in r. 30 of the rules framed under the Citizenship Act has to be made and no such enquiry had at all been made.

Though we are upholding the decision of the High Court, we wish to observe that we do number do so for the reasons mentioned by it. It is unnecessary to discuss those reasons but we would like to point, out one thing, namely. that the High

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has clearly discharged the onus that lay on him under s. 9 of the Foreigners Act to prove that he was not a foreigner, by proving that he was born and domiciled in India prior to January 26, 1950, when the Constitution came into force and thereby had become an Indian citizen under Art. 5 a of the Constitution. He has further proved that he had never migrated to Pakistan. It has not been shown that the Central Government had made any decision with regard to him under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act that he has acquired a foreign nationality.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it cannot be held by any court that the respondent who was an Indian citizen has ceased to be such and become a foreigner. That being so, it must be held for the purpose of this case that the respondent was not a foreigner and no order could be made against him under s. 3(2)(c) of the Foreigners Act. Conviction for breach of such an order by the respondent would be wholly illegal.

Though we are upholding the decision of the High Court, we wish to observe that we do number do so for the reasons mentioned by it. It is unnecessary to discuss those reasons but we would like to point, out one thing, namely. that the High
